questions.text: A 30 month old male child was brought with history of fever, and respiratory distress. Suspecting pneumonia , a chest xray was ordered. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus pneumoniae

 

Chest xray of child shows air filled cysts within lung parenchyma which are also known as pneumatoceles, and these are caused by staphylococcus pneumoniae.

 

Staphylococcus pneumoniae can cause primary or secondary pneumoniae (eg post influenza)

 

Clinical features – dyspnea, tachycardia, high fever, abdominal pain.

 

Staphylococcus aureus is also associated with complications like early development of empyema , pneumatocele , pyopneumothorax and bronchopleural fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella pneumoniae: While this organism can cause pneumonia, it is more commonly associated with pneumonia in adults with a characteristic "currant jelly" sputum and does not typically lead to pneumatocele formation.

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: This is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia but typically does not cause pneumatoceles. It usually presents with lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Often causes atypical pneumonia in older children and young adults, characterized by a more gradual onset of symptoms and a less severe clinical picture compared to bacterial pneumonia. Pneumatoceles are not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:


Staphylococcus aureus can cause severe pneumonia in children, often complicated by the formation of pneumatoceles and other serious complications such as empyema and bronchopleural fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option in Guillain Barre syndrome? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Steroids

 

Steroids are not effective in the treatment of Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) and do not improve outcomes. This has been confirmed by multiple studies and clinical trials, leading to their non-recommendation in GBS management protocols.

 

While steroids have no role in acute GBS treatment, they are used in managing Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP), which is a related condition that requires long-term immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin): IVIG is a widely accepted treatment for GBS, where it is used to modulate the immune response. The typical regimen involves a total dose of 2 g/kg given over 2-5 days. IVIG is believed to neutralize circulating antibodies and reduce inflammation, leading to a decrease in the severity and duration of the disease.

 

Option C. Plasmapheresis: Also known as plasma exchange, plasmapheresis is used in GBS to remove harmful antibodies from the blood. This treatment is particularly useful in severe cases and is often started within the first two weeks of symptom onset for maximum effectiveness.

 

Option D. Ventilator support: Because GBS can lead to paralysis of the muscles used for breathing, ventilator support may be necessary for patients with severe respiratory muscle weakness. This supportive care is crucial in managing life-threatening complications of GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steroids are not recommended for treating Guillain-Barre Syndrome due to their lack of efficacy in this specific condition, while IVIG and plasmapheresis are effective treatments. Supportive care, such as ventilator support, plays a vital role in managing severe cases where respiratory muscles are compromised.

 

Reference - Harrison neurology, Immune mediated neuropathies/GBS/Chap 447/12730

questions.text: EEG pattern given below is suggestive of which of the following diseases? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Creutzfeldt- Jakob Disease

 

Periodic sharp wave complexes occurring every 1 second is usually seen in sporadic CJD.

 

Spongiform encephalopathy characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism.

 

**Startle myoclonus is very peculiar feature observed in CJD.

 

Signs on MRI:

 

  • Sporadic CJD: 80-90% - Cortical-Ribbon sign on MRI.
  • Variant CJD: Hockey-stick appearance on MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic encephalopathies show triphasic wave (Negative-positive-negative waves).

 

Option B. GTCS shows high voltage, spike wave discharges in all leads.

 

Option D. HSV show periodic lateralized epileptiform discharge (PLED) arising from temporal lobes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease is associated with distinct EEG findings that are crucial for its diagnosis. Understanding the typical EEG patterns along with clinical presentation and advanced imaging can aid in the early and accurate diagnosis of this rapidly progressive and fatal disease.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology/Dementia/chap 438/12420

questions.text: 60-year-old lady presented with chest pain and exertional dyspnea. Her family says she was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. ECG on arrival is suggestive of Anterior wall MI. Her son succumbed to Severe COVID-19 pneumonia. CAG showed normal epicardial coronaries. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress.

 

Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure. Beta2 (Gs stimulation) at base and Beta2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimic ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. No signs of infection/Inflammation are given in the history. In presence of stress and temporal association, infection less likely.

 

Option C. Normal CAG rules out significant macrovascular CAD.

 

Option D. HCM shows dagger like q waves, SAM, Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy on ECHO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can present with symptoms and ECG changes similar to those of an acute myocardial infarction, but it is distinguished by normal coronary arteries on angiography and is often precipitated by severe emotional stress, fitting the patient's recent personal history.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259.

questions.text: Pancreatic cancer has the highest association with: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz Jegher’s syndrome

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is significantly associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer. PJS is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of benign polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and distinctive pigmented spots on the skin. It is caused by mutations in the STK11 (LKB1) gene. Individuals with PJS have a markedly increased risk of developing several types of cancer, including a 36% lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer, which is considerably higher compared to the general population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FAMMM Syndrome: While FAMMM (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma) syndrome, associated with mutations in the p16/CDKN2A gene, increases the risk for melanoma and pancreatic cancer, its association with pancreatic cancer is not as strong as that seen in PJS.

 

Option B. FAP (Familial Adenomatous Polyposis): FAP, primarily known for its high risk of colorectal cancer, also has some association with other cancers including pancreatic cancer, but again not as high as PJS.

 

Option C. Hereditary pancreatitis: Typically caused by mutations in the PRSS1 gene, hereditary pancreatitis does increase the risk for pancreatic cancer, but the risk is less compared to PJS.


Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic cancer has highest association with Peutz Jeghers syndrome.

 

Hereditary risk factors -

 

  • Peutz Jeghers syndrome- STK 11 (LKB1)
  • Hereditary pancreatitis – PRSS1 / SPIN 11
  • Cystic fibrosis – CFTR
  • FAMMM (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma)- p16/ CDKN2A
  • Hereditary breast &ovarian cancer- BRCA2
  • HNPCC/ Lynch syndrome – MLH1, MSH2, MSH 6, PMS2

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in rheumatoid arthritis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Febuxostat

 

Febuxostat is not used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor primarily used as a hypouricemic agent for managing gout by reducing uric acid production. Its primary function is to alleviate the symptoms and prevent the recurrence of gout, not to treat inflammatory or autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Leflunomide: Incorrect choice for the given answer as Leflunomide is indeed used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that works by suppressing the immune system to reduce inflammation.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Incorrect because Methotrexate is a cornerstone treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. It is another DMARD that helps reduce joint damage and decrease the pain and swelling associated with RA.

 

Option D. Etanercept: Incorrect as it is also used in rheumatoid arthritis treatment. Etanercept is a TNF (tumor necrosis factor) inhibitor, which is a type of biologic therapy that helps to decrease inflammation and slow disease progression in RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febuxostat is specifically used to manage gout by lowering uric acid levels and does not have a role in the treatment regimen for rheumatoid arthritis, which typically involves DMARDs and biologic agents aimed at controlling systemic inflammation and preventing joint damage.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap 358

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Syndrome Z? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL more than 100 mg/dl

 

Syndrome Z also known as Metabolic Syndrome, is characterized by a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. Syndrome involve the pressence of any three of the following five traits: 

 

Any 3/5 for diagnosis:

 

  1. Central Obesity: > 102cm (M),> 88 cm (F); [90(M), 80 cm (F) in Indians]: Only if questions specifically mention Indian population.
  2. BP > 130/85 mmHg
  3. FBS > 100 mg/dL/A1c
  4. Low HDL (in mg/dL): < 40 (F), < 50 cm(M)
  5. High TGL: > 150 mg/dL

 

Educational Objective:

 

While LDL cholesterol management is crucial in cardiovascular risk reduction, it is not one of the criteria for diagnosing Metabolic Syndrome, which focuses on abdominal obesity, blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastro/Fatty liver/Chap408

choices.text: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient's hands is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Early diagnosis of RA is crucial. May present with mono/oligoarthritis. Inflammation (stiffness > 30 mins) is significant.

 

RA +ve: 70%, anti-CCP+ve:75%. Hence 1/5th SERONEGATIVE

 

Rule out Psoriatic arthritis, Crystal arthropathies, CTD, Hansens, Polymyalgia rheumatica before labeling seronegative RA

 

Get baseline CBC, LFT, RFT, HbsAg, Anti-HCV

 

Start DMARD - Mtx 7.5-10 mg/week, gradually ↑ to 25 mg/wk. Avoid DMARDs cocktail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. OA usually morning stiffness <15-30 mins. Bouchard, Heberden nodes in late stages.

 

Option C. Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is a condition that can develop after peripheral nerve injury, wherein patients experience unprovoked pain in the area supplied by the affected nerve. Sympathetic innervation to the affected area can be disrupted, and blocking this sympathetic activity with a local anesthetic can sometimes alleviate the pain. Notably, damaged nerve fibers become sensitive to adrenergic signals, allowing them to be activated by the sympathetic nervous system. This constellation of symptoms, including spontaneous pain and signs of disrupted sympathetic function, characterizes CRPS.

 

Option D. Villonodular Synovitis is characterized by joint swelling due to excess synovial growth and potential bleeding into the joint, leading to pain and restricted movement, which is less likely given the chronic symmetrical joint involvement typical of RA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatoid Arthritis is suggested by the presence of symmetrical small joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the morning, with potential visible joint deformities. Early and aggressive treatment is vital to manage symptoms and prevent progressive joint damage.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap

questions.text: What is the most likely causative organism of ventilator-associated pneumonia among the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acinetobacter.

 

Acinetobacter species are particularly prevalent in hospital settings and are a common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). These organisms are known for their ability to survive on surfaces for extended periods and their resistance to multiple antibiotics, making them a significant concern in intensive care units where patients are often intubated. Acinetobacter, along with Pseudomonas and Stenotrophomonas, is known for colonizing the respiratory tract of ventilated patients, leading to VAP, which typically occurs after 48 hours of mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium: This genus, including species like Clostridium difficile, is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal infections, particularly antibiotic-associated diarrhea, rather than pneumonia.

 

Option B. Klebsiella: While Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause ventilator-associated pneumonia, it is generally less common than Acinetobacter in this specific infection context. Klebsiella tends to be more associated with community-acquired pneumonia and hospital-acquired infections outside of the ventilator context.

 

Option D. Haemophilus: Haemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections but is more commonly linked to community-acquired pneumonia and exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease rather than VAP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acinetobacter, pseudomonas, stenotrophomonas, Burkholderia cepacia are common organisms causing VAP. VAP occurs due to colonization by organisms in < 48 hours.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Pneumonia/Chap 142

choices.text: AIDP with migraine
Right side paralysis
Acute intermittent porphyria
Conversion disorder

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient came with complaints of vomiting and a decrease in movement of the right leg. In the past, she has had episodes of violent and aggressive behavior and abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute intermittent porphyria

 

Vomiting & decreased movements of right leg in young female with previous history of abdominal pain and mental symptoms like violent and aggressive behavior points towards acute intermittent porphyria.

 

Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder.

 

It is due to deficiency of HMB Synthase enzyme.

 

ACUTE INTERMITTENT PORPHYRIA

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Common precipitating factors include endogenous and exogeneous steroids, porphyrinogenic drugs, alcohol ingestion and low-calorie diets, usually instituted for weight loss.
  • Symptoms are more common in women, suggesting a role for estrogens or progestins.
  • Abdominal pain, the most common symptom is usually steady and poorly localized but maybe cramping.
  • Nausea, vomiting, constipation, tachycardia hypertension, mental symptoms, pain in the limbs, head, neck or chest, muscle weakness, sensory loss, dysuria, and urinary retention are characteristic.
  • The peripheral neuropathy is due to neurologic axonal degeneration (rather than demyelination) and primarily affects motor neurons.
  • Mental symptoms such as anxiety, insomnia, depression, disorientation, hallucination and paranoia can occur in acute attacks.
  • Seizures can be due to neurologic effects or to hyponatremia (due to hypothalamic involvement and inappropriate vasopressin secretion or from electrolyte depletion due to vomiting, diarrhea, poor intake or excess renal sodium loss).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • ALA & PBG levels are substantially increased in plasma and urine, especially during acute attacks.

 

Treatment:

 

  • I.V. Hemin is more effective and should be used as first line therapy for all acute attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AIDP with migraine: Incorrect because AIDP (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy) presents with rapid onset muscle weakness and decreased reflexes, not specifically associated with vomiting or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Right side paralysis: Incorrect as this diagnosis does not account for the broader spectrum of symptoms including behavioral changes and abdominal pain.

 

Option D. Conversion disorder: Incorrect because conversion disorder involves symptoms that suggest neurological or medical conditions but are actually manifestations of psychological conflict or needs. The specific clinical presentation and past medical history in this case strongly point towards a physiological rather than psychological cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The acute intermittent porphyria presents with a complex array of symptoms, including neurological, gastrointestinal, and psychiatric manifestations, and is associated with specific triggers and a genetic basis. Elevated ALA and PBG levels during attacks are diagnostic.

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with low free T4. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary hypothyroidism

 

HYPOTHYROIDISM

 

Types:

 

  1. Primary Hypothyroidism - Increased TSH with low T4 levels.
  2. Secondary hypothyroidism - TSH can be low, normal or elevated slightly. The latter is due to secretion of immune-active but bio-active forms of TSH. Confirmation of diagnosis is done by detecting low levels of unbound T4.

 

Evaluation of Hypothyroidism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Incorrect because subclinical hypothyroidism would show an elevated TSH but normal free T4 levels.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Incorrect as hyperthyroidism would typically present with low TSH and high free T4 levels.

 

Option C. Secondary hypothyroidism: Incorrect for this scenario because secondary hypothyroidism involves a problem with pituitary TSH production, which does not typically result in a significantly elevated TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH and low free T4 levels, indicating a failure of the thyroid gland itself to produce sufficient hormones.

questions.text: A diabetic patient walks into your clinic and does "namaste". The image is given below. What could be the probable cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cheiroarthropathy

 

Incomplete approximation of one or more of the digits when the patient attempts to approximate the palmar surfaces of the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints with palms pressed together and the fingers abducted.

 

It is associated with both Microvascular disease and macrovascular risk.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Flexor tenosynovitis: Involves inflammation of the tendon sheaths and is typically painful, which might include swelling and crepitus upon movement. It does not typically present with the inability to approximate the palms as in cheiroarthropathy.

 

Option B. Dupuytren's contracture: Results in fibrosis of the palmar fascia leading to permanent bending of the fingers into the palm. Unlike cheiroarthropathy, Dupuytren's typically produces visible nodules and cords in the palm, pulling the fingers inward.

 

Option D. Ankylosis: Involves the complete fusion of a joint leading to total immobility. This would manifest as rigid, immovable joints in fixed positions, not merely stiff and difficult to approximate as in cheiroarthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cheiroarthropathy is a significant indicator of chronic diabetic complications affecting the connective tissue. Recognizing this condition is important as it often correlates with other microvascular complications of diabetes such as retinopathy and nephropathy, prompting comprehensive management of the patient's diabetes to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Which part of the internal capsule is affected in hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior Limb

 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule is the most commonly affected area in cases of hemiplegia due to ischemic stroke. This area carries the corticospinal tract, which is essential for motor control. When the posterior limb is compromised, it disrupts the corticospinal pathway, leading to muscle weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body from the lesion.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: Primarily involved in visual processing. Damage here would likely lead to visual field defects rather than motor dysfunction.

 

Option B. Anterior limb: Primarily associated with cognitive and emotional functions due to its connectivity between the thalamus and the frontal lobe. Lesions here generally do not cause hemiplegia.

 

Option C. Sublentiform: Involved in auditory and gustatory pathways, thus unrelated to motor control functions affected in hemiplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ischemic stroke, damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in hemiplegia because of the disruption of corticospinal tracts. This knowledge aids in accurate stroke localization and informs rehabilitation strategies to help regain motor functions.

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Glucose

 

Rheumatoid pleural effusion, associated with rheumatoid arthritis, typically presents with low glucose levels, making high glucose the correct answer as it is not a characteristic found in such effusions. The low glucose in rheumatoid pleural effusion is due to increased metabolic activity of leukocytes and pleural cells which consume glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RA factor: The presence of RA factor (Rheumatoid factor) in pleural fluid is commonly seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid factor is an autoantibody found in the blood of approximately 80% of adults with rheumatoid arthritis. Its presence in pleural fluid reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of the disease.

 

Option B. Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals in the pleural fluid are indicative of a long-standing effusion, which can occur in chronic rheumatoid pleuritis. These crystals form as the pleural fluid becomes more concentrated over time due to the chronic nature of the inflammation.

 

Option D. High LDH: High levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the pleural fluid are a common feature of exudative effusions, including those caused by rheumatoid arthritis. LDH is an enzyme present in most cells and is released into the pleural fluid when cells are damaged or destroyed, reflecting the inflammatory processes occurring in rheumatoid pleuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

 

Lewy body dementia (LBD), also known as dementia with Lewy bodies, is characterized by specific core clinical features. Orthostatic hypotension, while commonly observed in LBD due to autonomic dysfunction, is not classified as a core clinical feature but rather as a supportive feature for diagnosis.

 

Central feature: Dementia (Essential for the diagnosis of DLB).

 

Core Clinical criteria include the following:

 

  1. Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  2. Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.
  3. Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD).
  4. Spontaneous cardinal features of parkinsonism.

 

Supportive Features of LBD:

 

  • Autonomic Dysfunction: Including orthostatic hypotension.
  • Severe Sensitivity to Antipsychotic Drugs: Patients may experience severe motor and neuroleptic sensitivity.
  • Other Hallucinations and Neurological Signs: Can include auditory hallucinations or transient, unexplained loss of consciousness.

 

Onset of dementia preceding or within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism differentiates Lewy Body dementia from Parkinson's disease with dementia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluctuating cognition: Fluctuating cognition is one of the hallmark symptoms of LBD, characterized by significant variations in attention and alertness. This fluctuation is more pronounced than what is typically seen in other forms of dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, and can vary from hour to hour or day to day.

 

Option B. REM sleep behavior disorder: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a core feature of LBD, where patients physically act out their dreams, often vividly. This disorder is a result of the loss of normal muscle atonia that should occur during REM sleep, leading to potentially violent movements and vocalizations during sleep.

 

Option C. Recurrent visual hallucinations: Visual hallucinations in LBD are typically well-formed and detailed, often involving people or animals. These hallucinations are a core feature and differ from the more nebulous or less structured hallucinations seen in other disorders. They are thought to be due to the underlying Lewy body pathology affecting cortical brain areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

 

Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

choices.text: Aspirin & clopidogrel
Decompressive surgery
Mechanical thrombectomy

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with history of a cerebrovascular accident 2 days ago. The patient is drowsy with minimal response. CT findings is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompressive surgery

 

The CT scan image shows significant edema and midline shift affecting more than 50% of the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) territory. This extensive edema, along with the patient's low Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, indicates severe brain swelling and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). In such cases, medical management alone (like mannitol for reducing ICP) may not be sufficient.

 

Guidelines for urgent decompression:

 

  • NIH Stroke scale > 15
  • Time < 48 hours
  • Age 18-60yrs
  • Territory infarct > 145cm3 or > 50% MCA territory
  • Informed consent that surgery improves survival but the patient may have significant disability.

 

Medical management of brain edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) may not be successful when significant swelling occurs in the cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere.

 

Therefore, a decompressive craniectomy should be considered to relieve the mass effect of the swollen cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere on the thalamus, brainstem and network projections to the cortex, which is manifested predominantly by decreased levels of arousal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin & clopidogrel: Incorrect as these medications are used for preventing further thrombotic events but are not suitable in the acute management of severe edema and brain shift.

 

Option B. Mannitol: Incorrect for sole use in this severe case, as it might not adequately control the mass effect and high ICP shown.

 

Option D. Mechanical thrombectomy: Incorrect because the primary issue in the CT image is the significant brain swelling and herniation risk, not an occlusion that can be resolved by thrombectomy at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cases of significant cerebral edema with midline shift, as seen on CT in acute stroke settings, decompressive surgery is often necessary to prevent fatal outcomes and manage increased intracranial pressure effectively.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

The correct choice is B, Dexamethasone, because the symptoms described (fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates) suggest the patient may be experiencing differentiation syndrome, which can occur following the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) with agents like Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by such symptoms and can improve with the administration of Dexamethasone. Dexamethasone is also used intrathecally in children for treating Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), indicating its relevance in managing severe inflammatory reactions in hematological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine: This option is incorrect as Cytarabine is primarily used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia and not specifically indicated for the management of differentiation syndrome in APML.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin: Incorrect because Doxorubicin is utilized for its efficacy against various cancers including Hodgkin's disease, cancer of the breast, and thyroid but is not suitable for treating differentiation syndrome in APML. It is also known for its cardiotoxic effects.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Incorrect as it is not recommended in the treatment regimen for APML and does not address the immediate complications of differentiation syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs

 

Reference - Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presented to the casualty with Hb - 5.4 g/dL, urea-86 mg/dL, creatinine- 6 mg/dL, calcium - 12 mg/dL, potassium - 4.4 mEq/L. Bone marrow aspiration shows > 60% of plasma cells. What is the next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone + Fluids

 

Features are suggestive of Multiple myeloma presenting with Mild Hypercalcemia with no pulmonary edema. Hence, treatment with steroids and IV fluids are recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dialysis is recommended if Hyperkalemia, Pulmonary edema, refractory acidosis, and Uremia.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone + lenalidomide is recommended in definitive therapy for MM along with bortezomib +/- Daratumumab (Anti CD38).

 

Option D. Bone marrow transplant is considered upfront in high-risk disease as definitive therapy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Immediate management of a newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patient presenting with anemia, renal failure, and hypercalcemia should prioritize rapid medical intervention to stabilize the patient. This includes hydration and the use of steroids to reduce plasma cell proliferation and calcium levels. Subsequent treatments will be based on the patient’s response and overall treatment strategy.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Plasma cell dyscrasia/Chap 111

questions.text: Calculate the GCS Score in an intubated patient, with findings of eye movements to pain and abnormal flexion? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E2VNTM3.

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is used to assess the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury and other conditions. In this scenario, the patient is intubated, which affects the ability to assess the verbal response. The current nomenclature for denoting non-testability due to intubation is "NT" (Non-testable) for the verbal component.

 

  • Eye Opening (E): The patient opens eyes in response to painful stimuli, which scores 2.
  • Verbal Response (V): The verbal component is non-testable (NT) due to intubation.
  • Motor Response (M): The patient exhibits abnormal flexion (decorticate response), which scores 3.

 

This combination gives a GCS score of E2VNTM3.

 

 

NT = non-testability of the corresponding component.

 

Used mainly in acute TBI (Traumatic brain injury).

 

Update:

 

1. GCS-P Score takes pupillary activity into consideration.

 

P = Pupillary non-reactivity

 

2 = Both pupil

 

1 = One pupil

 

0 = None

 

Minimum = 1, Max = 15.

 

2. FOUR score (Full outline of unresponsiveness) is currently employed having better sensitivity, specificity and PPV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In intubated patients, the GCS verbal score is marked as "NT" for non-testable. The GCS remains a vital tool in assessing the level of consciousness, particularly in emergency and critical care settings, ensuring that changes in the patient’s neurological status are promptly recognized and appropriately managed.

 

Reference - Harrison/Neurology/Basics /Chapter 443-TBI

choices.text: BP > 160/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives
BP > 160/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives.

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above goal despite the concurrent use of three anti-hypertensive agents of different classes. Typically, one of the three medications should be a diuretic, and all agents should be prescribed at optimal dose amounts. The threshold set for defining resistant hypertension is blood pressure greater than 140/90 mmHg.

 

Resistant hypertension indicates a situation where blood pressure control is inadequate despite the use of multiple medications, which can pose significant risks for cardiovascular complications and requires careful evaluation for secondary causes. This includes assessing for white-coat HTN/Pseudo HTN, medication adherence, lifestyle factors, and secondary causes of hypertension like renal artery stenosis, endocrine disorders, or medication-induced hypertension.

 

Home BP monitoring, ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring) can help in optimization of drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resistant HTN refers to BP > 140/90 mmHg despite three anti-HTN, one being a diuretic.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Cardiology/Hypertensive Disease/ chap 277

choices.text: Endobronchial neoplasm
Bronchial asthma
Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myasthenia gravis

 

In patient 1, flow volume curve shows restrictive pattern, and it corresponds to myasthenia gravis.

 

The flow volume curve shown indicates a restrictive pattern, which is characterized by reduced lung volumes but relatively preserved flow rates, consistent with non-obstructive lung pathology. Myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder, often affects the respiratory muscles leading to a restrictive ventilatory defect as depicted in the flow volume loop. This condition results from antibodies that block or destroy nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the junction between the nerve and muscle, leading to muscle weakness including the respiratory muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endobronchial neoplasm: Typically presents with an obstructive pattern on spirometry due to airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: Asthma would show an obstructive pattern characterized by decreased peak expiratory flow and difficulty exhaling, which is not observed in the given curve.

 

Option D. Emphysema: Emphysema, part of chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD), would also exhibit an obstructive pattern with a "scooped out" appearance on the expiratory curve due to air trapping and reduced elastic recoil, which is not seen in the curve provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis can present with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests due to respiratory muscle weakness, differentiating it from conditions that cause obstructive patterns such as asthma and emphysema.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with difficulty in micturition and defecation. There was no history of a cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cauda-Equina syndrome

 

Spinal cord ends at L1. Hence to accommodate the mismatch between vertebra and cord, the conus is formed from T12-L2 vertebral level housing the sacral portion of the cord. The lumbosacral roots descend downwards from conus and exit the corresponding foramina.

 

Sacral (S2,3,4) are responsible for sensations of the bladder wall. Hence injury leads to absent sensation and bladder distension with dribbling of urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pott's Spine: Incorrect because Pott's disease (tuberculosis of the spine) typically presents with chronic back pain associated with systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and weight loss due to the infection.

 

Option B. Guillain Barre Syndrome: Guillain Barre Syndrome primarily presents with ascending paralysis starting from the feet upwards, and sphincter involvement is rare, especially as an initial symptom.

 

Option D. Multiple Sclerosis: Incorrect because Multiple Sclerosis involves demyelination primarily affecting the brain and spinal cord but typically causes chronic, rather than acute, symptoms, and would not likely present with acute bladder and bowel dysfunction without other neurological signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cauda Equina Syndrome presents with acute lower back pain and severe disturbances in bladder and bowel control due to compression of the nerve roots in the lumbar and sacral areas, requiring urgent medical attention to prevent permanent damage.

 

Reference - Harrison/Neurology/Diseases of spinal Cord/Chap 442

choices.text: Start antibiotics and send samples for culture

questions.text: A patient who is intubated had an X-ray done. The radiograph is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ultrasound guided aspiration

 

Chest radiograph shows Unilateral Left pleural effusion. In the absence of suspicion for transudative effusion, thoracocentesis is indicated in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suction with percussion physiotherapy is recommended in suspected collapse due to mucus plugging etc.

 

Option B. Antibiotics are initiated if suspicion of severe CAP is present.

 

Option C. Chest physiotherapy is given to reduce collapse and pulmonary rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks
Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units as single dose
Benzathine penicillin 12-24 million units for 21 days

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of late cardiovascular syphilis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks.

 

Late cardiovascular syphilis is a form of tertiary syphilis that typically requires intensive antibiotic treatment to effectively manage the disease. The recommended regimen for treating this condition involves the administration of Benzathine penicillin G at a dose of 2.4 million units administered intramuscularly once a week for a total of three weeks. This regimen is effective because it maintains a therapeutic level of penicillin in the blood over a prolonged period, which is necessary for eradicating the persistent Treponema pallidum bacteria responsible for syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Nothing, since CT was normal
Start on aspirin + clopidogrel
Advice BP control

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and CT shows dense MCA sign. What would be your next step? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous thrombolysis

 

The patient's presentation of acute left-sided facial paralysis and weakness, alongside the finding of a dense MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) sign on a CT scan, indicates an acute ischemic stroke. The dense MCA sign is a radiologic indicator of a thrombus or embolus in the MCA, which is one of the most common sites for cerebral infarctions.

 

Given that the symptoms began only 1 hour ago and the CT has confirmed the location of the occlusion without showing any signs of hemorrhage or extensive infarction (which would contraindicate thrombolysis), intravenous thrombolysis is the most appropriate intervention. This treatment is aimed at dissolving the clot and restoring blood flow to the affected area of the brain.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nothing, since CT was normal: Incorrect because the CT was not normal; it showed a dense MCA sign, indicating an acute stroke.

 

Option B. Start on aspirin + clopidogrel: This would generally be considered in secondary prevention after the acute management phase of ischemic stroke, or if the patient was not a candidate for thrombolysis.

 

Option D. Advice BP control: While controlling blood pressure is important, it is not the immediate next step in the management of a patient showing signs of acute ischemic stroke with a window for thrombolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute ischemic stroke with clear indications, intravenous thrombolysis should be administered as soon as possible within the therapeutic window to improve outcomes. Immediate evaluation and management are critical to maximize recovery and minimize long-term disability.

choices.text: Acute kidney injury (AKI)
Chronic renal failure

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

 

The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease) criteria are specifically designed to classify and diagnose Acute Kidney Injury (AKI). These criteria help in early detection and grading the severity of AKI based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and duration of symptoms.

 

Current diagnosis is based on the KDIGO group criteria. Urine output (OR) Creatinine rise is considered in the diagnosis.

 

KDIGO group criteria for diagnosis of AKI:

 

  1. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 0.3mg/dL.
  2. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 1.5 times of baseline that is known/presumed to have occur in the past 7 days.
  3. Urine volume < 0.5ml/kg/hour for 6 hours.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute glomerulonephritis: This has specific clinical and laboratory features distinct from AKI.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: Characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over months to years.

 

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome: Defined by high levels of protein in the urine, low levels of protein in the blood, high levels of cholesterol, and swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AKIN and RIFLE criteria are essential tools for diagnosing and assessing the severity of Acute Kidney Injury, which can guide interventions and predict outcomes in affected patients. They emphasize changes in serum creatinine and urine output as key indicators of kidney function.

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in medicine ward with fever. What could be the possible diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Image shows typical biphasic illness with initial leptospiremic phase followed by immune phase.

 

Other illness that shows biphasic pattern include measles, Tick borne encephalitis virus, rarely Zika virus.

 

Modified Faine Criteria is used for diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monophasic illness with predominant CNS and multisystem involvement.

 

Option C. Undulant fever presenting with PUO, muscle pain, thoracic backpain

 

Option D. Enteric fever causes step ladder pattern of fever.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a biphasic fever pattern, especially when supported by epidemiologic data pointing to possible exposure to contaminated water or animals. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as Weil's disease, which can lead to severe renal and hepatic issues.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Leptospirosis/Chap 184

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Continue treatment for another 2 years
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment
Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics

questions.text: A 16-year-old who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue treatment for another 2 years

 

In cases of epilepsy, particularly in children and adolescents, the continuation of antiepileptic drug (AED) therapy after a period of being seizure-free is typically recommended for about 2 years. This recommendation is based on the need to stabilize neurological function and minimize the risk of recurrence. The decision to discontinue AEDs should consider factors such as the duration of being seizure-free, EEG findings, the type of epilepsy, and the individual’s neurological examination.

 

Rationale for Continuing Treatment:

 

  • Continuing AED treatment for at least 2 years after achieving seizure control helps ensure the stability of the condition and reduces the likelihood of seizure recurrence, especially during the critical developmental years of adolescence.
  • Recurrences are most common in the first 3 months after discontinuing AEDs, making a cautious approach necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop the treatment and follow up: This would be risky given the short period of seizure freedom (only 6 months). Stopping treatment prematurely may lead to recurrence.

 

Option C. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This is typically considered after a longer period of seizure freedom, usually a minimum of 2 years, not just 6 months.

 

Option D. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This is generally reserved for cases of refractory epilepsy where seizures cannot be controlled with multiple medications, which does not seem to be the case here based on the information provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-epileptics once initiated must be continued for a minimum period of 2 years. Decision to stop AED is considered if, seizure free > 2 years with normal MRI, EEG, seizure type.

 

Recurrences occur in the first 3 months of discontinuing AED.

 

Reference - Harrison principles of internal Medicine 21st edition Pg. 12076

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.text: The value of TG and VLDL are high in chronic diabetes because of which of the following reasons: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity.

 

In chronic diabetes, increase in hormone sensitive lipase and decrease in lipoprotein is seen, due to which values of TG and VLDL are increased.

 

Insulin has inhibitory effect on hormone sensitive lipase. In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in hormone sensitive lipase activity. This promotes breakdown of lipids and release of TG, and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

 

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase, which is present on capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and degradation of transport proteins, VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to increase in VLDL and TG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase: Incorrect because in diabetes, the activities of these enzymes are reversed; HSL activity is increased, and LPL activity is decreased.

 

Option C. Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors: Incorrect because LDL receptor function generally affects LDL levels, not directly influencing VLDL or triglyceride levels.

 

Option D. Increased in activity of hepatic lipase: Incorrect for this context as hepatic lipase primarily affects the metabolism of HDL and to a lesser extent LDL, not directly impacting TG and VLDL levels in the way described for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In chronic diabetes, the combination of increased hormone sensitive lipase activity (due to low insulin levels) and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity leads to higher levels of triglycerides and VLDL. This reflects the central role of insulin in lipid metabolism regulation.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man, post-MI, had the following lab values. Which of the following must be his treatment plan? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

 

LDL - 125mg/dl

 

HDL - 33mg/dl

 

TGL - 270mg/dl
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atorvastatin 80 mg

 

Post-MI patients require aggressive management to reduce the risk of future cardiovascular events. The lab values indicate elevated LDL and triglycerides, along with low HDL. The treatment plan includes the use of high-intensity statin therapy, which is recommended to significantly lower LDL cholesterol as part of secondary prevention strategies in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). Atorvastatin 80 mg falls under the category of high-intensity statins and is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol significantly, which helps in reducing the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rosuvastatin + fenofibrate: This combination might be considered if there were specific concerns about triglyceride levels that could not be managed by statin therapy alone. However, the primary goal post-MI is to manage LDL levels aggressively with high-intensity statins.

 

Option C. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate primarily targets triglycerides and would not be the first choice when the primary objective is to lower LDL cholesterol post-MI.

 

Option D. Rosuvastatin 10 mg: While rosuvastatin is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol, a lower dose may not be sufficient for high-risk patients post-MI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high-intensity statin therapy, such as atorvastatin 80 mg, is essential in the management of patients after an MI to reduce the risk of subsequent cardiovascular events, regardless of initial cholesterol levels. This approach aligns with guidelines that emphasize aggressive LDL reduction in patients with established cardiovascular disease.

choices.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.text: A diabetic nephropathy patient is an ideal candidate for renal graft transplant. Which of the following statements is true? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

 

In the absence of graft rejection, transplantation is financially advantageous for a patient with diabetic nephropathy. When compared to two years of dialysis, transplant surgery is less expensive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Graft survival rate is ~80-82% at the end of first year.

 

Option B. The life expectancy of a patient with diabetic nephropathy is not doubled post-transplant.

 

Option D. Chronic graft rejection following renal transplantation is referred to as chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN) which consists of tubular atrophy, glomerulosclerosis, fibrosis of the renal interstitium, and fibrous thickening of the arteries.

 

HLA mismatching, acute episodes of graft rejection, age mismatch between donor and recipient, smoking, and acute episodes of graft rejection are risk factors that put a recipient at risk for long-term graft rejection. Treatment is difficult and no significant improvement has been seen over last 10 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal transplantation becomes cost-effective after the second year post-transplant for diabetic nephropathy patients compared to ongoing dialysis. This consideration, coupled with improved quality of life and potential prolongation of life expectancy, makes it a favorable option for suitable candidates.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins

 

The correct answer is B, Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins. This combination is effective against Burkholderia cepacia, a pathogen known for its resistance to many standard antibiotics. The standard regimen includes Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), which has broad-spectrum bacterial coverage, combined with a 3rd generation cephalosporin such as ceftazidime or cefoperazone-sulbactam to cover for the pathogen's unique resistance profiles and aggressive infection nature, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with existing cardiac issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminoglycoside and colistin: This option is incorrect due to the intrinsic resistance of Burkholderia cepacia to aminoglycosides. While colistin could still be effective, the resistance to aminoglycosides limits this combination's usefulness.

 

Option C. Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporin: Incorrect because the combination of carbapenems with cephalosporins is generally not recommended. They both share a similar mechanism of action, inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis, and could potentially compete for the same binding sites, thus reducing their effectiveness.

 

Option D. Cefepime and tigecycline: Incorrect because tigecycline is not particularly effective against Burkholderia cepacia. Cefepime alone would not sufficiently manage the infection due to the bacteria's robust resistance profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard regimen for Burkholderia cepacia is cotrimoxazole with ceftazidime /cefoperazone-sulbactam.

questions.text: Calculate the anion gap from the following values: Na+ = 137 mmol/L; K+ = 4 mmol/L; CI- =100 mmol/L; HCO3- = 15 mmol/L? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 22 mmol/L

 

AG = (Sum of cation) - (Sum of anion)

 

AG = (Na - (HCO3 + CL))

 

AG = 137 – 115 = 22 mmol/L

 

Note: Normal AG ~ 12

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Dialysis will prevent all except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripheral Neuropathy

 

Dialysis is effective in removing many waste products and toxins from the blood, which can alleviate a range of symptoms associated with uremia. However, it is less effective in preventing or reversing complications that arise from the accumulation of middle molecular weight substances, such as those implicated in peripheral neuropathy.

 

 

Peripheral neuropathy in dialysis patients is largely attributed to the build-up of middle molecular weight molecules like beta 2 microglobulin, which are not efficiently removed by standard dialysis membranes. Native kidneys or high-flux dialyzers are more effective at removing these molecules, but even these can have limited efficacy. Peripheral neuropathy is thus a complication less responsive to conventional dialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seizures: These are often caused by severe uremia or electrolyte imbalances, both of which can be effectively managed through dialysis.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: Dialysis helps correct metabolic acidosis by removing excess acids from the blood and restoring bicarbonate levels.

 

Option D. Uremic pericarditis: Uremic toxins that contribute to inflammatory conditions such as pericarditis are effectively removed through dialysis, thereby preventing this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While dialysis effectively manages many complications of renal failure such as seizures, metabolic acidosis, and uremic pericarditis, it is less effective for peripheral neuropathy due to its limited ability to remove middle molecular weight toxins that contribute to nerve damage. Ongoing management and treatment strategies need to consider these limitations.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Nephrology, Dialysis

questions.text: Definition of PUO includes all of the following except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Undiagnosed after one week of investigation

 

The correct answer is C because the definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) does not specify that the fever must remain undiagnosed for only one week. According to the established criteria for diagnosing PUO, the investigation can be longer and more thorough before labeling a fever as PUO. The criteria include a fever exceeding 38.3°C on at least two occasions, persisting for more than three weeks, and a diagnosis that remains uncertain after comprehensive history taking, physical examinations, and routine investigations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fever persisting for more than 3 weeks: This is incorrect because it is a part of the definition of PUO, where the fever must last for more than three weeks.

 

Option B. Immunocompromised status should be ruled out: This is incorrect  as a choice because being non-immunocompromised is a criterion in the diagnosis of PUO, which means any immunocompromised status should indeed be ruled out.

 

Option D. Temperature more than 38.3°C: This is also incorrect as it is part of the criteria, where the temperature must be more than 38.3°C on multiple occasions to consider it as PUO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Criteria for diagnosis of PUO:

 

  • Fever > 38.3 degrees C (101° F) on 2 occasions.
  • Duration > 3 weeks.
  • Not immunocompromised state.
  • Diagnosis not certain after history, physical examination and routine and obligatory investigations.

questions.text: A 25yr old woman came to OPD one year after the birth of her last child. She had been treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. On examination, she is pale, and investigations show a HB of 5mg/dl and a reticulocyte count of 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count ? (take normal Hb as 15mg/dl) (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Corrected reticulocyte count (CRC)= reticulocyte % X (actual Hb/normal Hb)

 

CRC= 9 X 5/15 = 3%

 

CRC can also be calculated using hematocrit

 

CRC= Reticulocyte % X (Actual PCV/ normal PCV )

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) adjusts the observed reticulocyte percentage to reflect the degree of anemia by using the patient's actual hemoglobin compared to a normal hemoglobin level.

 

The corrected reticulocyte count is crucial for assessing bone marrow response in anemic patients, providing insight into whether the bone marrow is responding appropriately to the anemia. This is particularly important in managing patients with iron deficiency anemia to monitor recovery or response to therapy.

choices.text: SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg

questions.text: All of the factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age < 60 years

 

The ABCD2 score is a clinical tool used to predict the short-term risk of stroke after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The scoring system includes several factors that help assess this risk. Here’s why option A is the correct answer:

 

  • Age < 60 years: According to the ABCD2 scoring system, a patient who is aged 60 years or older scores 1 point, indicating a higher risk. Therefore, being younger than 60 does not contribute to an increased score, making it the correct choice for the exception in this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duration of TIA > 5 mins: In the ABCD2 score, the duration of the TIA is an important factor. TIA lasting 10-59 minutes scores 1 point, and TIA lasting more than 60 minutes scores 2 points. Duration less than 10 minutes would score 0. However, since the option simply says "Duration of TIA > 5 mins," without specifying how much longer, it's less clearly defined in this question, but generally longer durations imply a higher score.

 

Option C. SBP > 140 mm Hg and DBP < 90 mmHg: High blood pressure at the time of TIA, defined as SBP ≥ 140 mm Hg or DBP ≥ 90 mm Hg, scores 1 point in the ABCD2 score.

 

Option D. Diabetes: The presence of diabetes in a patient who has experienced a TIA adds 1 point to the ABCD2 score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional D3-Dual TIA (within 7 days of first TIA), Imaging (MRI, DWI) were added to original score. However, all these perform very poorly in the light of recent evidences.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Yogurt

 

Yogurt is the least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance among the options listed. This is because yogurt contains live bacteria, specifically lactobacilli, which help to break down lactose. This fermentation process reduces the lactose content significantly, making yogurt easier to digest for individuals with lactase deficiency. Additionally, these bacteria can contribute to the production of some lactase enzyme, aiding in the digestion of any remaining lactose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skimmed Milk: Contains nearly the same amount of lactose as regular milk, just with less fat. It is likely to cause symptoms in someone with lactose intolerance.

 

Option B. Condensed Milk: Even higher in lactose because it is milk that has been concentrated by removing water. High lactose content makes it more likely to cause intolerance symptoms.

 

Option C. Ice-cream: Typically high in lactose because it is made from cream and milk, both of which are high in lactose. Ice cream can also contain mix-ins and flavorings that increase the lactose content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yogurt contains lactobacillus, that helps in lactase production and also low lactose levels.

 

Reference - Harrison/Gastroenterology/Diarrhea/chap 471

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypercalcemia 

 

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs due to destruction of large no of rapidly proliferating neoplstic cells. It is characterised by Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia , hyperphosphasphatemia, hypocalcemia, acidosis, acute renal failure.

 

It mainly occurs after initiation of chemotherapy and is diagnosed by Cairo bishop criteria (includes both lab and clinical features)

 

Management includes - allopurinol , rasburicase along with aggressive hydration .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Typically occurs as phosphate is released from lysed tumor cells.

 

Option B. Hyperuricemia: Results from the metabolism of nucleic acids from destroyed cells.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Occurs due to the release of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space.

 

Educational Objective:


In tumor lysis syndrome, the rapid breakdown of tumor cells leads to hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, making this the key distinguishing feature in identifying the condition. Management strategies like hydration, use of allopurinol, or rasburicase are critical in preventing renal failure and other serious complications.

questions.text: Noninvasive test to detect hepatic fibrosis include? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibro test

 

The FibroTest, also known as the Fibro test, is a noninvasive, blood-based test designed specifically to detect hepatic fibrosis. This test calculates the degree of liver fibrosis using a combination of several serum biochemical markers including haptoglobin, bilirubin, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), apolipoprotein A1, and alpha-2 macroglobulin. It evaluates liver damage and fibrosis by measuring these markers, which are affected by liver function and architecture changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspartate aminotransferases /platelet ratio (APRI): Incorrect as it is primarily used to estimate the likelihood or severity of fibrosis rather than to directly detect it. It correlates with the degree of liver fibrosis but is less specific.

 

Option C. Forns index: Incorrect for the same reason as APRI. The Forns index is used to assess the risk of developing liver fibrosis based on variables including age, platelet count, cholesterol levels, and GGT, but it does not directly measure fibrosis.

 

Option D. Serum laminin & serum hyaluronidase: Incorrect as these are not standard tests for directly detecting hepatic fibrosis; they can indicate changes in extracellular matrix turnover but are less specific and commonly used compared to the FibroTest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibro test is a sensitive test to detect hepatic fibrosis. It is a multiparameter blood test which incorporate haptoglobin, bilirubin, GGT, apolipoprotein A1, and alpha-2 macroglobulin.

 

Test for estimating risk developing hepatic fibrosis:

 

  1. AST/platelet ratio
  2. Forns index
  3. Fib-4
  4. Cirrhosis determinant score.

 

Test for detecting hepatic fibrosis: Fibro test.

choices.text: HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HCV, Anti HEV
HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HDV, Anti-HEV, Anti-HCV

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male chronic smoker presents to the AIIMS OPD with fever, fatigue, yellow-colored urine, and RUQ pain. For the past few days, he has developed an aversion to eating food. On examination icterus was present. What investigations would you advise to rule out acute viral hepatitis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)


Liver function test results are given below:

 

  • Total Bilirubin 18.5
  • Direct Bilirubin 10.5   
  • SGOT/AST 723
  • SGPT/ALT 812
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-HAV, HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HCV

 

Above history is suggestive of acute viral hepatitis with ALT>AST and elevated >10X times. With resolution of symptoms jaundice gradually increases and spontaneously improves.

 

Common causes of AST, ALT > 10X are Viral Hepatitis (B, A, C-rare, E-In pregnancy/Post-transplant), Toxins, Shock liver, Fulminant Wilsons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HEV testing routinely not employed

 

Option C. Hepatitis D usually causes severe disease when B+D coinfection occurs.

 

Option D. HbsAg is first test of hep B infection W/IgM HbC suggest FLARE, window period, acute infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected acute viral hepatitis with significant liver enzyme elevation and icterus, it's essential to conduct a thorough serological evaluation to determine the specific type of hepatitis virus involved. This allows for targeted management and appropriate precautions to prevent transmission.

 

Reference: Harrison/gastroenterology/Viral Hepatitis/Chap 339

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is commonly used for treating community-acquired pneumonia in OPD? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Azithromycin

 

Decision for OPD vs Admission for CAP is assessed by CURB-65, PSI score.

 

For patients with risk factors (CKD, non-ambulator, Recent ABx, hospitalization last 3 months), macrolide + Beta-lactam /Respiratory FQ preferred.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Vancomycin given only if CA-MRSA is considered.

 

Suspicion for MRSA:

 

1. Necrotizing/Cavitary pneumonia

2. Pleural based nodules

3. Post viral pneumonia

4. Treatment failure (Sx, hypoxemia, MODS @ 72 hours post admission)

5. IVDU

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone is given for IP treatment and administered I.V.

 

Option D. Streptomycin is not used in management of CAP.

 

Educational objective:

 

Azithromycin is a commonly used antibiotic for the outpatient treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to its effectiveness against a wide range of respiratory pathogens and its patient-friendly dosing schedule.

 

Reference - Harrison/Respiratory /Pneumonia/Chapter 126

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the most useful diagnostic investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT Thorax

 

CECT is preferred when suspicion of malignancy is high. HRCT is preferred to look at lung parenchyma/suspected ILD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI is used to assess for metastasis, secondary changes. MRI is NOT preferred over CT scan for evaluation of distant metastasis and invasion.

 

Option B. Bronchoscopy is used for biopsy of mass based on accessibility. More central masses are amenable to bronchoscopic biopsy. Peripheral masses are sampled by CT-guided biopsy.

 

Option D. Bronchography is no longer used in today’s practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The choice of CT Thorax (HRCT or CECT) is critical for early detection of potential malignancies or other significant lung conditions in a high-risk individual, particularly when initial less sensitive tests like chest X-ray and sputum analysis have failed to elucidate the cause of symptoms.

 

Reference - (Harrison 21E, 597,598) Resp Med/Hemoptysis/Lung CA

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
It is protective against H. pylori infection
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

 

Polycythemia vera (PV) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells. It is commonly associated with a mutation in the JAK2 gene, which can also affect other cell types, including mast cells. Activation of these cells can lead to the release of histamine, which is thought to contribute to the itching or pruritus often experienced by patients, particularly after warm baths or showers.

 

Myeloproliferative neoplasms include PCV, CML, and PMF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis: Incorrect. Although thrombocytosis is present in polycythemia vera, thrombosis risk correlates more significantly with leukocytosis and the presence of JAK2 mutation rather than solely with thrombocytosis.

 

Option B. It is protective against H. pylori infection: Incorrect. There is no evidence to suggest that polycythemia vera provides protection against H. pylori infection. Patients with PV actually may have an increased risk of gastrointestinal issues.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality: Incorrect. While patients with polycythemia vera do have an increased risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the most common cause of mortality in these patients is thrombotic events such as heart attack or stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generalized pruritus in polycythemia vera, exacerbated by warmth or bathing, is a well-known symptom related to mast cell activation due to the JAK2 mutation. This mutation is a hallmark of the disease and leads to several systemic effects, including increased histamine release, which contributes to pruritus.

 

All MPN can develop AML, Myelofibrosis in the course of the disease.

choices.text: Can be cultured in a cell-free medium

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mycoplasma pneumonia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Responds well to amoxiclav

 

Beta-lactam groups of drugs act by inhibiting the transpeptidation process of cell wall synthesis. Mycoplasma does not possess a cell wall and hence is not affected by beta-lactams.

 

Azithromycin (DOC), Doxycycline, Fluoroquinolone (FQ) are effective in management of mycoplasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interstitial inflammation characterized by bilateral reticular infiltrates are seen on CXR.

 

Option C. IgM, IgG can be used in the diagnosis of Mycoplasma.

 

Option D. They show fried-egg appearance on cell free medium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycoplasma pneumonia does not respond to beta-lactam antibiotics due to its lack of a cell wall.

 

The preferred antibiotics for treating Mycoplasma pneumonia include macrolides (e.g., azithromycin), tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline), and fluoroquinolones for adults.

 

Reference - Resp Med/pneumonia, Harrison chap 188/5430

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleuritis with/without pleural effusion.

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion is the most common pulmonary manifestation in patients with SLE. This condition reflects the systemic inflammatory nature of SLE, which frequently affects serous membranes including the pleura. Pleural involvement in SLE typically presents as an exudative pleural effusion, often characterized by pleuritic pain and effusion that can be detected by physical examination and imaging studies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shrinking lung syndrome: is very rare occurring in 1% of patients. Some association with Anti-Ro/La antibodies seen. No correlation between disease activity, symptoms and antibodies.

 

Option B. Intra Alveolar hemorrhage and D. Interstitial inflammation: are not the most common presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleuritis with or without pleural effusion stands out as the most frequent pulmonary complication in SLE due to the disease’s propensity to inflame serous membranes. Accurate diagnosis and effective management of SLE and its pulmonary manifestations are crucial for improving quality of life and reducing morbidity in affected patients.

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MRI imaging is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD) is a rare, genetic, demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system characterized by a distinctive "tigroid" pattern on MRI. This pattern arises from the preservation of perivascular myelin in the brain's white matter, interspersed with areas of demyelination, creating a striped or tigroid appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pantothenate kinase deficiency: This condition is also known as PKAN (Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration). It typically shows a characteristic MRI feature known as the "eye of the tiger" sign, which involves a specific pattern of iron deposition in the basal ganglia. The "eye of the tiger" sign appears due to a combination of hyperintense signal surrounded by a region of hypointensity on T2-weighted MRI images, reflecting iron accumulation and gliosis. This is distinct from the tigroid pattern seen in demyelinating diseases.

 

Option B. Neuroferritinopathy: Neuroferritinopathy is another disorder of iron metabolism that affects the brain, leading to iron accumulation, particularly in the basal ganglia. MRI findings in neuroferritinopathy typically do not include the tigroid pattern but may show abnormalities such as signal changes in the basal ganglia related to iron deposition. The imaging features here are more associated with iron accumulation rather than the patchy demyelination that produces the tigroid appearance.

 

Option D. Aceruloplasminemia: Aceruloplasminemia is a rare hereditary disorder characterized by iron accumulation in various tissues, including the brain. Similar to neuroferritinopathy, the primary MRI findings in aceruloplasminemia are related to iron deposition, particularly in the cerebellum and basal ganglia, and do not typically involve the tigroid pattern. Instead, the imaging might show evidence of iron accumulation without the specific changes associated with demyelination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is a prototypical condition that displays a tigroid pattern on MRI. This appearance is due to the patchy preservation and destruction of myelin in the white matter, creating alternating areas of normal myelin and demyelination. This results in the characteristic striped or tigroid appearance on imaging studies, reflective of the disease’s impact on myelination.

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactants ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albumin

 

Negative acute phase reactants are substances whose serum concentrations decrease in response to systemic inflammation. Albumin is one of the well-recognized negative acute phase reactants. Its levels fall during acute phase response as resources are shifted to produce more critical positive reactants that help in the defense and repair processes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haptoglobin: This is a positive acute phase reactant, which increases in response to inflammation.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Also a positive acute phase reactant, often increases in states of inflammation and infection.

 

Option D. C-reactive protein: A classic positive acute phase reactant, it increases dramatically in response to inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Closure of tricuspid valve
Onset of ventricular systole
Maximal atrial filling

questions.text: 'a' wave in JVP corresponds to? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right atrial contraction

 

The 'a' wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) represents right atrial contraction. This occurs towards the end of ventricular diastole and reflects the pressure increase within the right atrium as it contracts to push blood into the right ventricle just before the tricuspid valve closes.

 

Other Options:
