Option B. Closure of tricuspid valve: Incorrect, this would not be specifically represented by an 'a' wave; instead, it typically follows the 'a' wave and leads into the 'c' wave associated with right ventricular contraction.

 

Option C. Onset of ventricular systole: Incorrect, ventricular systole corresponds to the 'c' wave and the 'x' descent on JVP.

 

Option D. Maximal atrial filling: Incorrect, maximal atrial filling occurs towards the end of the 'v' wave and into the 'y' descent, which corresponds to passive ventricular filling when the tricuspid valve is open.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Harrison/Cardiology/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: A 60-year gentleman was referred from outside hospital to AIIMS ER after he developed sudden onset quadriparesis. In hospital patient was treated with 3%NaCl, Oral tolvaptan. Initial metabolic panel revealed Na: 115 mEq/L, K: 2.8 mEq/L, Cl: 85 mEq/L with normal TSH, CBC, RFT, LFT.  What is the most likely cause for this patient's condition?  (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osmotic demyelination syndrome

 

Previously called central pontine myelinolysis. It occurs due to rapid correction of Chronic Hyponatremia (>8 mg/dL).

 

Timing: 2-6 days after rapid correction.

 

Rx: Irreversible. Desmopressin clamp if overcorrection in q6h Na values.  

 

Mechanism:

 

1. In Hyponatremia

 

 

2. On sudden correction:

 

 

Risk factors:

 

  1. Serum sodium ≤ 105 mEq/L
  2. Concurrent hypokalemia
  3. Chronic excess alcohol intake
  4. Acute or chronic hepatic disease
  5. Malnourishment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain infarct: Not directly suggested by the rapid onset of symptoms following electrolyte correction.

 

Option B. Brainstem injury: Could be considered but is less likely without trauma or vascular insult history.

 

Option D. Rare cause of hypernatremia: Not applicable as the condition involves the rapid correction of hyponatremia, not hypernatremia itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia should be avoided to prevent the severe neurological complications associated with osmotic demyelination syndrome. Control and monitoring of serum sodium levels are crucial during treatment.

 

Reference - Harrison/Electrolytes/Chap 53

choices.text: Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg

questions.text: All are components of CURB65 except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Systolic blood pressure less than 10mm Hg

 

The correct answer, D, specifies a systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg, which is not part of the CURB-65 criteria. The specified threshold for blood pressure in the CURB-65 is ≤90 mm Hg systolic or ≤60 mm Hg diastolic.

 

CURB-65 criteria is used to assess the severity of illness in case of pneumonia, especially community acquired pneumonia. It includes 5 variables -

 

C - Confusion

 

U - Urea>7mmol/L

 

R - Respiratory rate >30/mins

 

B - Blood pressure, SBP </=90 mmHg or diastolic </= 60 mmHg

 

65 - Age >/= 65 years

 

Management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CURB-65 scoring system is used to evaluate pneumonia severity, which does not include systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg but instead sets the threshold at ≤90 mm Hg systolic or ≤60 mm Hg diastolic.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is due to which of the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asthenospermia

 

Asthenospermia (Immotile sperm [Greek sthenos = strength]

 

Kartagener result from loss of function of axonemal dynein that impairs sperm motility. Respiratory Ciliary dysmotility leads to bronchiectasis and recurrent infections. Association of situs inversus is noted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oligospermia: Incorrect because while sperm count can be affected in some genetic or hormonal disorders, in Kartagener's syndrome, the sperm count is typically normal; the issue lies in their motility.

 

Option C. Epididymis obstruction: Incorrect as this is not a feature of Kartagener’s syndrome. While structural anomalies in the reproductive tract can lead to such issues, Kartagener’s syndrome specifically affects the motility of sperm due to ciliary dysfunction.

 

Option D. Undescended testes: Incorrect as undescended testes are not associated with Kartagener’s syndrome, which primarily affects ciliary function and not the anatomical position of the testes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is primarily due to asthenospermia, which is caused by the immobility of sperm. This immotility results from the genetic defect affecting the dynein arm of sperm flagella, similar to the defect affecting cilia in the respiratory tract, leading to the classic symptoms of the syndrome.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Bronchiectasis/Chapter 290

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, diplopia, hoarseness, dysphagia and left Horner's syndrome associated with numbness of the left face and right-side limbs. Which artery is affected in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Lateral Medullary syndrome/Wallenburg syndrome which occurs due to PICA occlusion. His syndrome is characterized by a range of neurological deficits due to ischemia in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata, where PICA provides blood supply.

 

Clinical Features Associated with PICA Occlusion:

 

  • Vertigo and Diplopia: Caused by the involvement of the vestibular nuclei and adjacent structures.
  • Hoarseness and Dysphagia: Result from damage to the nucleus ambiguous, affecting the vagal and glossopharyngeal nerve functions.
  • Horner’s Syndrome: Occurs due to disruption of the sympathetic pathways.
  • Numbness of the Face and Contralateral Limbs: Caused by damage to the spinal trigeminal nucleus and the spinothalamic tract, respectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA): Affects a similar region but typically presents with symptoms like hearing loss due to its supply to the inner ear structures, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option C. Superior Cerebellar Artery: Occlusion typically results in ataxia and coordination difficulties without the cross-sensory loss observed in Wallenberg's Syndrome.

 

Option D. Basilar Artery: A much broader array of symptoms would be expected, potentially affecting multiple cranial nerve and long tract functions simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Image: Arteries involved in brainstem syndromes lateral vs medial brainstem

 

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Chap 426, Neurology/stroke

choices.text: Oral glucose challenge test with GH level
Insulin like growth factor 1 binding potein -3 (IGFBP-3 )
Insulin like growth factor -1 levels
Random growth hormone levels

questions.text: A 44 yr old man is referred to your center for management of severe hyperglycemia. During examination, you note that patient has enlarged feet, coarse facial features, and prognathism. You suspect acromegaly. Which of the following tests can you use as a screening method for this condition ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulin like growth factor-1 levels

 

Acromegaly is a clinical syndrome that results from excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH). Produced mainly in the pituitary gland, GH controls the physical growth of the body. In adults, too much of this hormone causes bones, cartilage, body organs, and other tissues to increase in size. Acromegaly is most often diagnosed in middle-aged adults, but symptoms can appear at any age. In children, too much growth hormone causes a condition called gigantism rather than acromegaly.

 

Best screening test for acromegaly is serum insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral glucose challenge test with GH level: While this test is used to diagnose acromegaly by demonstrating a lack of GH suppression after glucose administration, it is more complex and typically performed after IGF-1 screening suggests acromegaly.

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factor 1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3): Although IGFBP-3 levels are influenced by GH, they are not routinely used for screening acromegaly.

 

Option D. Random growth hormone levels: These levels can fluctuate significantly throughout the day and are influenced by various factors, making random GH levels unreliable for diagnosing acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum IGF-1 is the preferred initial test for screening acromegaly due to its reliability and the persistence of elevated levels in the presence of excessive GH production. This test provides a stable indicator of disease activity and is less variable than direct GH measurements.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old smoker who is a known case of hypertension was on enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide. He had an episode of hemoptysis and on evaluation, he was found to have bronchogenic carcinoma with brain metastasis. His lab values were Na-124mg/dL, creatinine - 2.8mg%, blood sugar 112mg/dL, blood urea - 24mg/dL, serum osmolality 255mosm, urine osmolality - 110 mosm, 24-hour urinary sodium - 110 and BP - 150/90 mmHg.

 

Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis of the low sodium values in him? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SIADH

 

Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) is the most probable diagnosis in this patient. The diagnostic criteria and the patient's clinical presentation support this conclusion:

 

 

Additionally, lung cancer (specifically bronchogenic carcinoma) can often cause SIADH, either through ectopic production of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or related paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diuretic induced hyponatremia: Incorrect because the pattern of serum and urine osmolality does not align solely with diuretic use; the high urine sodium and euvolemia are more indicative of SIADH.

 

Option C. Cerebral salt wasting syndrome: Incorrect as this condition typically presents with hypovolemia and low blood pressure due to significant sodium and fluid loss, which is not evident in this patient who maintains a normal blood pressure.

 

Option D. Pseudohyponatremia: Incorrect because the reduced serum osmolality directly indicates true hyponatremia, not a distortion caused by high levels of lipids or proteins in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SIADH can be associated with malignancies like lung cancer, presenting with hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and inappropriately concentrated urine despite the presence of low plasma osmolality. This clinical scenario should prompt consideration of SIADH, particularly in patients with known malignancies and typical lab findings.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with a history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia presents to the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myxedema coma

 

Myxedema coma is part of myxedema crisis which can be considered as “Decompensated Hypothyroidism”, where, organ dysfunctions occur compared to hypothyroidism (functioning is fairly preserved).

 

It is characterized by:

 

  1. Hypothermia
  2. Hypotension
  3. Hypoventilation
  4. Altered Mental Status (including coma /Hypersomnolence)
  5. Hyponatremia (Euvolemic similar to SIADH)
  6. Hypoglycemia

 

Adrenal insufficiency may co-exist. Hence, treated with IV steroids + IV levothyroxine/Nasogastric LT4.

 

Steroid given to prevent precipitation of adrenal crisis as well.

 

Often precipitated by infection or major cardiopulmonary or neurologic illness. Rarely precipitated by severe cold climate exposure.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. No obvious source, fever suggestive of septic shock given in the question.

 

Option B. No cardiac symptoms, elevated JVP, cardiac risk factors.

 

Option C. Dry-skin, hypotension, hypothermia, menorrhagia as presentation of Hypoglycemia is unlikely.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases where a patient presents with hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status, especially in conjunction with a history suggestive of hypothyroidism, myxedema coma should be considered a critical diagnosis. Immediate and aggressive thyroid hormone replacement therapy is essential for survival.

choices.text: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing

questions.text: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mm Hg after 3 mins of standing

 

“3-20-10” mnemonic can aid in remembering the definition of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Sustained fall of SBP > 20mmHg /DBP > 10mmHg after 3 mins of standing. Usually, it is accompanied by a rise in HR. Absence of increase in heart rate suggest neurogenic/autonomic dysfunction.

 

Cause of Orthostatic Hypotension:

 

  • Cardiac pump failure
  • Hypovolemia
  • Endocrinopathies: AI, Pheochromocytoma.
  • Venous pooling
  • Medications

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and B: These options extend the timing to 6 minutes, which is not standard for the initial assessment of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Option D: Specifies a diastolic drop which should be 10 mmHg, not 20 mmHg, thus making it incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postural hypotension, also known as orthostatic hypotension, is defined as a significant drop in blood pressure when a person stands up from a sitting or lying position. The correct definition, as per the consensus, includes a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 20 mmHg or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg within 3 minutes of standing. The answer C correctly reflects the component of this definition regarding the systolic blood pressure drop.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology, chap 21/695

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation
Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation
Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.32, pCO2 = 50, HCO3- = 29. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate:

 

pH = 7.12 (<7.4 = acidemic/acidosis) → Metabolic vs respiratory (pCO2 > 40= Respiratory drive is towards acidosis while metabolic [HCO3-] is towards alkalosis) → Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation (Every 10 ↑ pCO2 = ↑4 HCO3- = Chronic).

 

These findings are characteristic of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. In respiratory acidosis, the body compensates by increasing renal reabsorption of bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions resulting from elevated CO2 levels, which shifts the pH back towards normal. This compensation is a slower process and suggests a chronic respiratory condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where ABG shows a low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory high bicarbonate, the diagnosis is typically respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. This is indicative of a chronic condition where the body adjusts bicarbonate levels to buffer the increased acidity due to CO2 retention.

 

Reference - Harrison/Acid-Base Disturbances

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuromyelitis optica

 

Bilateral optic neuritis with extensive transverse myelitis and partial steroid response is suggestive of NMO-Spectrum disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MS usually causes U/L optic neuritis. LETM (Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis) not common in MS.

 

Option C. SACD usually affects the posterior column. LETM, optic neuritis not a feature of B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Neurosyphilis is usually associated with RAPD (U/L Optic neuritis). LETM not common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINGERCHUK Criteria for NMO-SD

questions.text: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EGPA

 

Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome, is characterized by a combination of asthma, eosinophilia, and vasculitis affecting multiple organ systems.

 

The clinical triad of skin lesions (such as purpura or nodules), asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex (manifesting as numbness, pain, or muscle weakness typically in the limbs), and eosinophilia is highly suggestive of this condition. EGPA is a type of ANCA-associated vasculitis but differs from others in its prominent eosinophilic involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis: Typically associated with hepatitis C infection and features immune complexes in the blood that precipitate in the cold. It commonly presents with palpable purpura, joint pains, and kidney involvement but not typically with eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): A medium vessel vasculitis that may present with similar features including neuropathy and skin lesions but does not typically include eosinophilia as a prominent feature.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis (GCA): Primarily affects large vessels, particularly the temporal arteries, and presents with symptoms such as headache, jaw claudication, and potential blindness. It does not feature the triad of skin lesions, mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EGPA is a distinctive form of vasculitis marked by asthma, eosinophilia, and a systemic vasculitis involving skin and nerves among other systems. Its recognition is crucial due to the need for early and aggressive treatment to prevent significant morbidity and mortality.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multifocal atrial tachycardia             

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VT is usually regular and wide QRS tachycardia (QRS > 120ms).

 

Option B. P waves usually absent in AF.

 

Option D. Atrial tachycardia is regular narrow QRS tachycardia with fixed morphology of P wave.

 

Note:

 

  • MAT is usually associated with lung disease and occurs secondary to underlying hypoxemia.
  • Treatment is with CCB > BB to slow the atrial, ventricular rate.
  • Cardioversion is ineffective and contraindicated in this rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia is characterized by multiple ectopic atrial activities leading to variable P wave morphologies and an irregular rhythm, often associated with underlying chronic pulmonary conditions. Management focuses on treating the underlying condition and stabilizing the rate with appropriate medications.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/chap 250/7033

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong about DIC? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased fibrinogen

 

Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a complex condition characterized by systemic activation of blood clotting, which results in the generation and deposition of fibrin, leading to microvascular thrombi in various organs and contributing to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. As a part of this process, there is widespread consumption of clotting factors and platelets, which leads to a paradoxical increase in bleeding risk.

 

  • Increased fibrinogen is incorrect because in DIC, fibrinogen is typically decreased, not increased. This decrease is due to its consumption during the formation of fibrin clots throughout the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% of patients w/DIC may have schistocytes on PS.

 

Option B. Consumption of clotting factors leads to ↑PT, aPTT. Presence of normal PT, aPTT w/schistocytes hints towards possibility of MAHA.

 

Option D. FDP are elevated due to activation of coagulation cascade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DIC, one typically sees a constellation of laboratory findings including decreased fibrinogen, increased PT and aPTT, elevated FDPs, and the presence of schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. These changes reflect both the excessive activation of the coagulation cascade and the secondary activation of fibrinolytic pathways, leading to the consumption of clotting factors and secondary bleeding complications.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hematology/Coagulation disorders

questions.text: What is not a feature of myasthenia gravis among the following? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absent deep tendon reflexes.

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatiguability of skeletal muscles. There is decrease in number of available acetylcholine receptors at neuromuscular junction due to an antibody mediated autoimmune attack.

 

  • Visual problems, including drooping eyelids (ptosis) and double vision (diplopia)
  • Muscle weakness and fatigue may vary rapidly in intensity over days or even hours and worsen as muscles are used (early fatigue)
  • Facial muscle involvement causing a mask-like appearance; a smile may appear more like a snarl
  • Trouble swallowing or pronouncing words
  • Weakness of the neck or limbs
  • Weakness increases during repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep.
  • Deep tendon reflexes preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle fatigue: This is a defining symptom of MG, characterized by increased muscle weakness with continued activity.

 

Option C. Normal pupillary reflex: MG primarily affects voluntary muscles and typically does not impact the autonomic functions, including pupillary reflexes which remain normal.

 

Option D. Ptosis: Ptosis, or drooping eyelids, is one of the common features of MG due to muscle weakness affecting the muscles that control eyelid elevation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deep tendon reflexes are preserved in myasthenia gravis despite significant muscle weakness and fatigability, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular disorders that might also lead to reflex abnormalities.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate were >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Check Blood sugar level

 

Evaluation of Common reversible emergency causes are targeted in the ER. Altered mental status occurring acutely can be remembered with MIST.

 

Step 1. Rx >>> Dx priority (↓ Glucose).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HTN emergency is treated with I.V. antihypertensives.

 

Option C. I.V. mannitol is used in the management of cerebral edema.

 

Option D. CT brain to be done after ruling out life-threatening reversible common causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of any comatose patient, particularly those with diabetes, should include rapid assessment of blood glucose levels to rule out hypo- or hyperglycemia as a reversible cause of the coma. This immediate action can be life-saving and should precede other investigations and treatments.

questions.text: What does the Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) measure?  (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anisocytosis

 

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) is a measure of the variation in red blood cell (RBC) size. Anisocytosis, which is the variation in the sizes of RBCs, is directly assessed by RDW. A higher RDW indicates a greater variation in size. RDW is used clinically to help differentiate between types of anemia and to provide insight into the underlying mechanisms of anemia. Normal RDW values range from 11-14%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochromia: Refers to RBCs having less color than normal, indicative of less hemoglobin content per cell, not directly related to RDW.

 

Option C. Poikilocytosis: Indicates variation in the shape of RBCs, not their size, hence not directly assessed by RDW.

 

Option D. Anisochromia: Refers to variation in hemoglobin content among RBCs, which is not measured by RDW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDW measures the variability in size of red blood cells, which is indicative of anisocytosis. High RDW is associated with conditions like iron deficiency anemia and other types of anemia, where there is significant variation in RBC sizes.

 

Additional Information

 

IDA vs Thalassemia

 

IDA- rbcs are small (low MCV ) with high RDW

 

Thalassemia- RBCs are small (low MCV )  with normal RDW

questions.text: In a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). All the following can be used for treatment except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptokinase

 

In the management of NSTEMI, the focus is on antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy rather than fibrinolytic agents like streptokinase. Streptokinase is specifically used in the treatment of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) where there is a fibrin-rich thrombus completely occluding a coronary artery. NSTEMI, in contrast, involves a partial occlusion by a platelet-rich thrombus, and fibrinolytics are generally not recommended because they are less effective and could potentially increase the risk of bleeding without significant benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: As a foundational antiplatelet agent, aspirin is used in both STEMI and NSTEMI to reduce platelet aggregation and further thrombus formation.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: This is another antiplatelet drug that is used in the management of both STEMI and NSTEMI as part of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) along with aspirin to provide greater protection against thrombotic events.

 

Option D. Prasugrel: Similar to clopidogrel, prasugrel is used in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) management, including NSTEMI, especially when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is planned, due to its potent antiplatelet effects. (Prasugrel is given peri-procedurally).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21e chap 118/3518

choices.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position
The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle.

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coagulopathy is not a contraindication.

 

The image depicts a spinal needle used primarily for lumbar puncture (LP), a procedure where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected from the lumbar cistern. The procedure can be conducted in either the lateral recumbent position or sitting position, depending on the patient's comfort and the physician's preference. The bevel orientation during insertion affects the dural fibers; positioning it parallel (typically upwards) minimizes dural fiber tearing and the subsequent likelihood of post-lumbar puncture headaches. Importantly, coagulopathy is a significant contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the increased risk of spinal hematoma and severe complications associated with bleeding around the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To be done in lateral recumbent position: This is true and is one of the standard positions for performing an LP.

 

Option B. Breath holding is not necessary: During LP, patients are advised to breathe normally to avoid increases in intra-abdominal and intrathoracic pressure, which could affect CSF dynamics.

 

Option C. The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle: This is a recommended practice to reduce the risk of post-procedure complications, such as a post-dural puncture headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coagulopathy is a contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the risk of bleeding and potential for serious complications, contrary to the incorrect statement provided. Always assess the patient’s coagulation status prior to performing an LP.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male came with complaints of ascending weakness in both lower limb and upper body. There was no history of trauma. Which of the following is the next investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum Potassium

 

Disturbance in serum potassium levels (hypokalemia or hyperkalemia) present with ascending muscle weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Magnesium: Incorrect for this scenario as disturbances in magnesium typically cause tetany (muscle spasms) when low and generalized weakness when high, but are less directly linked to the type of ascending muscle weakness described.

 

Option C. Serum Sodium: Incorrect because changes in serum sodium levels generally affect neurological function but do not typically cause muscular weakness.

 

Option D. Serum Calcium: Incorrect as calcium imbalances would more likely cause tetany (from hypocalcemia) or symptoms like fatigue, depression, and cardiac arrhythmias (from hypercalcemia), rather than ascending muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The disturbances in serum potassium levels can manifest as muscle weakness, making it a vital test in cases of unexplained, ascending muscle weakness without trauma.

questions.text: Below is a radioactive scan for thyroid pathology. which of the following is the most probable diagnosis: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypersecreting Adenoma

 

Image findings are suggestive of hypersecreting adenoma.

 

  1. Increased uptake in the right lobe at the thyroid
  2. Suppressed uptake in left lobe of thyroid

 

These findings are highly suggestive of a hypersecreting adenoma. This condition occurs when a benign tumor in the thyroid gland produces thyroid hormone independently of the normal regulatory mechanisms, leading to an overactive area (hot spot) in one part of the thyroid, with suppression of activity in the rest of the gland due to negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Incorrect as this type of cancer typically presents with a "cold nodule," which shows reduced or no uptake on a radioactive scan. The scan shows no areas of reduced uptake indicative of a cold nodule.

 

Option C. Grave’s disease: Incorrect because Grave's disease generally causes a diffuse increase in uptake across the entire thyroid gland due to widespread stimulation of thyroid tissue. The scan does not show diffuse uptake, which rules out Grave's disease.

 

Option D. Lateral aberrant thyroid: Incorrect as this condition involves ectopic thyroid tissue that might appear as functioning thyroid tissue outside the normal location. The scan does not indicate any ectopic thyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersecreting adenoma in the thyroid is characterized by increased radioactive uptake in one area of the thyroid with suppression in other areas, reflecting independent hormone production from the adenoma.

questions.text: Management of hyperkalemia includes all except : (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium sulphate

 

Magnesium sulfate is not typically used for the treatment of hyperkalemia. It is more commonly used in the management of eclampsia in pregnant women and for its neuromuscular blocking effects in various other medical conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

The management of hyperkalemia typically involves interventions that stabilize the cardiac membrane, shift potassium into cells, and remove potassium from the body. Common treatments include:

 

Option A. Calcium gluconate: Which stabilizes the cardiac membrane and does not lower potassium levels but protects the heart from the effects of hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Insulin drip: Often accompanied by glucose, which drives potassium back into cells, thereby lowering its serum concentration.

 

Option  C. Salbutamol nebulization: A beta-agonist that promotes the movement of potassium into cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of hyperkalemia

 

  • Calcium gluconate- reduces plasma K+ concentration by redistribution in cells rapidly
  • Insulin- lowers plasma K+ concentration by moving potassium intracellular, insulin dose used – 10units of IV regular insulin f/b 50ml of 50%dextrose
  • Salbutamol
  • Cation exchange resins, diuretics, dialysis.

questions.text: The serum electrolyte values of a patient weighing 60 kg are given below. Calculate the sodium deficit in the patient. pH: 7.42, Na+: 120 mEq/L, serum K+: 4 mEq/L, serum CI-: 90 mEq/L? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 720 mEq

 

Sodium Deficit = Body weight x (0.6) x (desired sodium- actual sodium) [Note: 0.5 if female]= 60*0.6*(140-120) = 720 mEq.

 

Note: Correction should not exceed 6-8 mEq/day in chronic hyponatremia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium deficit -

 

Rate of Correction: It's critical to correct chronic hyponatremia slowly to avoid complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. The recommended rate of correction should not exceed 6-8 mEq/L per day.


Monitoring: Frequent monitoring of serum sodium levels is necessary during the correction phase to adjust the treatment as needed and prevent overcorrection.

 

Ref: Harrison 21/Fluid and electrolyte/Chap 53

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cladribine

 

It is a purine analogue used in the treatment of Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Cladribine-phosphates interfere with DNA synthesis and repair through incorporation into DNA and through inhibition of enzymes involved in DNA metabolism, including DNA polymerase and ribonucleotide reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D are not used in Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia patients have mutation in BRAF pathway and hence, Vemurafenib (BRAF inhibitor) is used as second line agent in refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cladribine remains the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia due to its high efficacy in inducing remissions.

questions.text: What is the window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 41/2 hours

 

The window period for the administration of intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) in the case of an acute ischemic stroke is 4½ hours from the onset of symptoms. This time frame is critical as rtPA is most effective when administered early, aiming to dissolve the blood clot and restore blood flow to the affected part of the brain, thus minimizing or reversing the damage caused by the stroke.

 

Indications:

 

  • After Clinical diagnosis of stroke established
  • If onset of symptoms to time of drug administration </= 4.5 hours
  • If age >/= 18 years
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory
  • Consent given by patient or surrogate

 

Contraindications:

 

  • Coma/stupor/ recent MI.
  • Major surgery in last 14 days/ GI bleeding in last 21 days/ minor stroke symptoms.
  • Rapidly improving symptoms.
  • Sustained BP > 185/110 mmHg despite treatment.
  • Platelets < 100,000; HCT < 25%; glucose < 50 or > 400 mg/dL.
  • Use of heparin within 48hrs and prolonged PTT or elevated INR.
  • Prior stroke or head injury within 3 months; prior intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic window for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke using rtPA is up to 4½ hours from symptom onset, and strict criteria must be met to ensure the safety and efficacy of treatment. This timeframe is crucial for maximizing the potential benefits of the treatment while minimizing risks.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paralysis agitans

 

The substantia nigra is the marked structure in the transverse section of the brain that is shown. Degeneration of the substantia nigra is observed in Parkinson's disease, commonly referred to as paralysis agitans.

 

Due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which aid in the manufacture of dopamine, the substantia nigra is pigmented. The substantia nigra lacks or has less pigmentation in Parkinson's disease.

 

Parkinson's disease is characterized by bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors. It's also known as paralysis agitans due to the motor dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: Incorrect because depression is typically associated with dysfunctions in other brain regions such as the prefrontal cortex and limbic system, not specifically the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Alzheimer’s disease: Incorrect as Alzheimer's disease primarily involves the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, leading to amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, rather than specific damage to the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Huntington chorea: Incorrect because Huntington’s disease involves degeneration of the striatum and other parts of the brain but does not primarily affect the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra's degeneration is central to the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease, manifesting as motor symptoms like bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors.

choices.text: Aspiration pneumonia – Upper segment of right lower lobe

questions.text: A 46-year-old diabetic presented with fever, malaise, and cough. His chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial infiltrates – Mycoplasma

 

The chest X-ray shows bilateral patchy infiltrates, particularly in the lower lobes. This pattern is characteristic of atypical pneumonia, specifically Mycoplasma pneumonia. In Mycoplasma infections, infiltrates tend to be interstitial and patchy, not dense consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobar infiltrates – Pyogenic pneumonia: Incorrect. Pyogenic pneumonia typically shows dense consolidation with air bronchograms in a lobar distribution

 

Option B. Hilar infiltrates – Malignancy: Incorrect. Hilar regions appear normal. Malignancy typically presents with hilar masses or lymphadenopathy

 

Option D. Aspiration pneumonia – Upper segment of right lower lobe: Incorrect. Although aspiration pneumonia often affects this segment, this patient shows no risk factors for aspiration and has bilateral infiltrates

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral patchy interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray, along with fever, malaise, and cough, are characteristic of atypical pneumonia, particularly Mycoplasma pneumonia.
